**Overview:** Wastewater reuse is widely practiced globally, particularly in agriculture, with significant scale in developing regions where untreated wastewater irrigation far exceeds treated wastewater use, highlighting both opportunities and health risks.

**Key Points:**
• Approximately 35 million hectares in the global South are irrigated using raw or diluted wastewater, primarily untreated or partially[Source 1].

• Treated wastewater reuse occurs at a scale thirty times smaller than untreated wastewater irrigation in many developing regions [Source 1].

• The Middle East and North Africa region has documented cases of successful water reuse, including urban landscaping and golf course irrigation in Morocco and Tunisia [Source 4].

• Guidelines and best management practices exist to improve the acceptance and safety of agricultural water reuse, addressing technical and governance challenges [Source 5].

**Implications:**
• Untreated wastewater reuse poses public health risks but supports urban agriculture where treatment is lacking.

• Scaling up treated wastewater reuse requires investment in infrastructure and harmonized governance frameworks.

• Successful cases in arid regions demonstrate wastewater's potential to alleviate water scarcity.

| **Practice** | **Scale/Region** | **Key Feature** |
|--------------|------------------|-----------------|
| Untreated wastewater irrigation | ~35 million hectares (Global South) | Predominantly informal, health risks [Source 1] |
| Treated wastewater reuse | Smaller scale (e.g., MENA) | Formal projects, urban landscaping [Source 4] |

Would you like to explore specific wastewater reuse guidelines or regional case studies in more detail?

references.content: Reuse of raw or diluted wastewater for irrigation of ﬁeld crops is practiced around most cities of the global South on a total area of up to 35 million hectares (Raschid-Sally and Jayakody, 2008; Thebo et al., 2017). Most of this irrigation is using untreated or at best partially treated wastewater, at a thirty times larger scale than the known areas using treated wastewater (Scott et al., 2010); Thebo et al., 2017.
